data.title: Gunther Eysenbach on LinkedIn: Nature ranks U of T among top three institutions in the world for health…
data.meta_description: Methodology: “For its first health sciences ranking, the Nature Index tracked the author affiliations of 9,200 articles in 64 medical journals.”. 64 journals!…
data.text:
LinkedIn and 3rd parties use essential and non-essential cookies to provide, secure, analyze and improve our Services, and to show you relevant ads (including professional and job ads) on and off LinkedIn. Learn more in our Cookie Policy.

Select Accept to consent or Reject to decline non-essential cookies for this use. You can update your choices at any time in your settings.

Methodology: “For its first health sciences ranking, the Nature Index tracked the author affiliations of 9,200 articles in 64 medical journals.”. 64 journals! Great marketing play by Springer Nature, but these self-serving “rankings” - counting mainly research in certain prestige journals (mostly Nature and Lancet) - are harmful for science and lead to unsustainable publishing costs. FYI, U of T also ranks highly in JMIR Publications journals, which publishes at a fraction of these costs, but what these rankings do is to make university administrators encourage their faculty to publish in certain journals (covering their APCs in transformative agreements) while bleeding out innovative publishing platforms and open access pioneers with no library budget left to support these.
